Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I sat at my desk, the weight of my dual callings pressing on my shoulders. As a lawyer, I was reviewing a confidential client file when my assistant, new to the firm, knocked and asked if she could access the documents to help organize the case. She seemed eager, wanting to prove herself, but I knew the strict boundaries of client confidentiality. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from a parishioner, gently asking if I might have time to meet for spiritual guidance in the coming days. I could sense the vulnerability behind the request, the hope for comfort and counsel. My mind raced—my legal role demanded unwavering discretion, while my priestly calling urged me to be present and open to those in need. I felt torn, the expectations of both worlds pulling me in opposite directions, each demanding my full attention and integrity. The tension built inside me as I tried to find a way to honor both responsibilities without betraying either trust.
